questions.text: During a routine dissection class, your professor asks you to identify the structures seen in the given specimen. Correctly match the following with their respective structures:

choices.text: 1- Putamen; 2- Globus pallidus; 3- Caudate nucleus; 4- Thalamus
1- Caudate nucleus; 2- Thalamus; 3- Globus pallidus; 4- Putamen
1- Thalamus; 2- Caudate nucleus; 3- Globus pallidus; 4- Putamen
1- Caudate nucleus; 2- putamen; 3- Thalamus; 4- Globus pallidus

questions.solution:
The correct match is: 1- Caudate nucleus, 2- Thalamus, 3- Globus pallidus, 4- Putamen. The given image shows the coronal section of the brain with different parts of the basal ganglia.

The basal ganglia constitutes accessory motor system that functions in close association with the cerebral cortex and corticospinal motor control system. On each side of the brain, these ganglia consist of the caudate nucleus, putamen, globus pallidus, substantia nigra, and subthalamic nucleus.

Nomenclature of basal ganglia:

  • Corpus striatum: Caudate nucleus + putamen+ globus pallidus
  • Lentiform nucleus: Putamen + globus pallidus
  • Neostriatum: Caudate nucleus + putamen 

The internal capsule separates the thalamus and the caudate nucleus from the lentiform nucleus. The caudate nucleus is a C-shaped mass of grey matter. It is divided into a head, body, and tail. Degeneration of the caudate nucleus is seen in Huntington's disease. 

Both the Putamen and external capsule lie lateral to globus pallidus. It receives fibers from the striatum and subthalamic nuclei. It acts as the main output of the basal ganglia to the thalamus and superior colliculus. The substantia nigra is seen in each cerebral peduncle of the midbrain located deep to the crus cerebri. The levels of dopamine in the substantia nigra and striata are reduced in parkinsonism disease.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man who was non-compliant with his tuberculosis medication now comes with back pain. You suspect the disease has disseminated to the spine. Which part in the given image of the spine, is most commonly affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, the patient is likely to have developed tuberculosis of the spine. The most common pattern of involvement in Pott's spine/ Tb spine is the paradiscal type.

The structures marked in the image:

  1. Posterior spinal elements
  2. Paradiscal area of the vertebra
  3. Anterior vertebral body
  4. Central vertebral body

Tb spine occurs secondary to a pulmonary or gastrointestinal primary and spreads through the Batson's plexus of veins (paravertebral plexus). It most commonly involves the dorso-lumbar region. 

Types of vertebral tuberculosis:

  • Paradiscal - contiguous areas of two adjacent vertebrae and the middle intervening disc are affected. This is due to the high oxygen requirements of tubercular bacteria and the corresponding high blood supply in this region by the segmental vessels.
  • Central - the body of the vertebra is involved leading to collapse (causing wedging or concertina) of the affected vertebra. This leads to spinal deformities such as kyphosis and gibbous.
  • Anterior - the anterior part of body is affected and spreads through the anterior longitudinal ligament.
  • Posterior - the posterior complex (pedicle, lamina, spinous process, and transverse process) is affected.

Image showing various parts and patterns of involvement in Pott's spine.

questions.text: The sequence of vitamin D synthesis is?
questions.solution:
The sequence of vitamin D synthesis is skin-liver-kidney.

The sequence of vitamin D synthesis:

Step 1: In the skin: 7-Dehydrocholesterol (an intermediate in cholesterol synthesis that accumulates in the skin) undergoes a nonenzymic reaction on exposure to ultraviolet light, yielding cholecalciferol, which is absorbed into the bloodstream.

Step 2: In the liver:  Cholecalciferol is hydroxylated to 25-hydroxycholecalciferol (calcidiol). This is released into the circulation bound to a vitamin D–binding globulin, which is the main storage form of the vitamin.

Step 3: In the kidney: 25-hydroxycholecalciferol is converted to either 1,25 dihydroxycholecalciferol (calcitriol), the biologically active form by the enzyme 1α-hydroxylase.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient presents to your primary health center with complaints of lethargy, easy fatiguability after heavy menses of 6 months duration. She looks visibly pale. On examination, her palmar creases are lighter than the surrounding skin on hyperextension of the hand. She is presumed to be anemic and iron supplements started. What could be her possible hemoglobin level based on the current clinical findings?
questions.solution:
Given scenario points towards a diagnosis of iron deficiency anemia. If the palmar crease is lighter than surrounding skin on the hyperextended hand, hemoglobin is likely to be < 8 g/dl.

Primary symptoms of iron-deficiency anemia include easy fatigability, tachycardia, palpitations, and tachypnea on exertion.

Severe deficiency causes skin and mucosal changes:

  • A smooth tongue
  • Brittle nails
  • Spooning of nails (koilonychia)
  • Cheilosis

Dysphagia because of the formation of esophageal webs (Plummer–Vinson syndrome) may occur in severe iron deficiency.

Pica (cravings for specific foods like ice chips, hair, paper, which are often not rich in iron) may occur in iron deficient patients.

questions.text: The given USG of lung shows:
questions.solution:
The given image shows the seashore sign seen in M-mode imaging of the normal lung.

M-mode is defined as the time-motion display of the ultrasound wave along a chosen ultrasound line. With M-Mode, even rapid motions can be displayed, measured, and recorded.

In the M-mode of USG, the motionless portion of the chest above the pleural line creates horizontal ‘waves', and the sliding below the pleural line creates a granular pattern, the ‘sand’. The resultant picture is one that resembles waves crashing in onto the sand and is therefore called the ‘seashore sign’ and is present in a normal lung.

Option A: Stratosphere sign or barcode sign is a finding in the M-mode seen as parallel horizontal lines above and below the pleural line. This is seen in pneumothorax.

Option C: There is no named sign called troposphere sign.

Option D: Mirror image artifact is seen when there is a highly reflective surface (eg: Diaphragm) in the path of the primary beam.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl presented with poor growth and social interaction as well as midline stereotypical movements of the hands as seen in the image below. All milestones were normal for the first 2 years. After that, the milestones delayed and her development slowed down. On examination, her gait was slightly clumsy, her speech had regressed to mere babbling and her anthropometry was below the 50th percentile. Following a battery of investigations, the diagnosis of a rare inherited disease was made. What is the affected gene for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given features of poor growth & social interaction, gradual loss of speech, clumsy gait along with the characteristic hand movements point towards a likely diagnosis of Rett’s syndrome. The gene involved in Rett’s syndrome is the MeCP2 gene located on the X chromosome (Xq28 predominantly of paternal origin). 

Rett’s syndrome:

  • Almost always affects girls (X- linked dominant)
  • Development may proceed normally until 1 year of age slowing down to the extent of regression. 
  • After 1 year of age, rapid regression in language and hand skills, motor milestones, and acquired microcephaly become apparent.
  • Clinical features can include repetitive hand wringing movements, ataxia, breathing dysfunction, bruxism, scoliosis, and profound mental retardation.
  • Autistic behaviour is a typical finding in all patients.

Note:

  • Rb: Retinoblastoma: 13 chromosome
  • P53: Li–Fraumeni syndrome, Sarcomas: 17
  • NF1: Neurofibromatosis 1-17
  • NF2: Neurofibromatosis 2-22
  • WT1: Wilms's tumour: 11
  • FGFR3: Achondroplasia

questions.text: What does the given image represent?
questions.solution:
The above image represents a hypnogram. It is a graph that depicts the stages of sleep as a function of time. It provides a visual representation of sleep structure and is useful in the diagnosis of various sleep disorders. 

An electroencephalogram is the depiction of the electrical activity of the surface of the brain. Different waveforms (alpha, beta, theta, delta) are produced depending on the functional status of the brain.

 

Polysomnography is a multi parametric test that is considered the gold standard in the diagnosis of sleep disorders. It is a continuous recording of biophysiological changes that occur during sleep. It includes,

  • Continuous EEG recording, from occipital and parietal leads
  • Electro-oculography- to record eye movements
  • Electromyography- for muscle potential and its activities
  • ECG
  • Multiple sleep latency tests- repeated measures of time taken to sleep
  • Nasal-oral airflow, respiratory effort, oxyhemoglobin saturation, and leg movements during sleep are measured.

 

Epworth sleep assessment scale is a questionnaire used to quantify daytime sleepiness. It determines how frequently a patient is likely to doze off in 8 commonly encountered situations. It is a subjective assessment and hence less reliable.

questions.text:
Match the following poisons with their probable mechanism of action
A. Zinc chloride 1.Abortifacient
B. Chloral hydrate 2. Irritant
C. Quinine 3. Corrosive
D. Potassium carbonate 4. Stupefying
questions.solution:
For the above-given options, the correct match is given as 

Poison Mechanism
A.Zinc Chloride 2. Irritant
B.Chloral hydrate 4. Stupefying
C. Quinine 1. Abortifacient
D.Potassium
carbonate		 3. Corrosive

The rationale for the classification:

Zinc chloride also known as butter of zinc is highly irritant to the eyes on topical application. It can cause erosive esophagitis on ingestion. It has a fatal dose of 350mg. It could've also been classified as a corrosive, but since potassium carbonate is an alkali with stronger corrosive action, it is better classified as an irritant for this question.

Chloral hydrate is a CNS depressant. It is also known as knockout drops because of its rapid action and is used in robbery or rape to quickly render the victim helpless.

Quinine is a cardiotoxic drug with the additional action of being an abortifacient. Its overdose may lead to an echolic action (contract the pregnant uterus)

Potassium carbonate is a caustic alkali with a predominantly corrosive action due to its high pH.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not responsible for an exacerbation of psoriasis?
questions.solution:
Levothyroxine is not implicated in exacerbations of psoriasis.

Drugs inducing/exacerbating psoriasis:

  • Beta-blockers
  • Synthetic antimalarials
  • NSAIDS
  • Lithium
  • ACE inhibitors & angiotensin receptor blockers
  • Interferon alpha
  • Tetracycline
  • Terbinafine
  • Gemfibrozil

Other environmental and immunological factors that may trigger psoriasis are:

  • Infections- beta-hemolytic streptococci can trigger guttate psoriasis
  • Alcohol misuse and smoking
  • Emotional stress
  • Trauma - Koebner phenomenon
  • Winter 
  • Sunlight

questions.text: A 30-year-old man who serves in the military presents with a swelling in the natal cleft with occasional purulent discharge from it. He also complains of pain, and difficulty in sitting. On examination, a single point of discharge is seen. There is hair at the opening, but no feces are present. Per rectal examination has no significant findings.  What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation of a military personnel with swelling in the natal cleft associated with pain and discharge is suggestive of pilonidal sinus disease/jeep disease. 

Pilonidal sinus disease is commonly seen in the natal cleft, more in men, usually after puberty. Drivers and hairdressers are more commonly affected.

The pilonidal sinus opening is seen usually in the midline between the level of the sacrococcygeal joint and the tip of the coccyx. The other sites that they can be affected include the interdigital cleft and axilla.

Pathophysiology:

Buttock friction and shearing forces in this area allow broken hairs to enter the skin and create a subcutaneous, chronically infected midline track. An infected hair follicle can also form such a track. Secondary tracks can also form and are lined with granulation tissue and discharge. 

Clinical features:

  • Patients complain of intermittent pain, swelling, and discharge at the base of the spine.
  • A foreign-body-type reaction may then lead to the formation of an abscess.
  • Recurrence is common even after adequate excision of the tract.

Treatment

  • Conservative treatment: Strict hygiene and regular shaving of hair in the area.
  • Abscess:
    • Rest, baths, local antiseptic dressings, and broad-spectrum antibiotics.
    • If refractory to the above treatment- drainage with thorough curettage of granulation tissue and hair.
  • Surgical techniques: Bascom’s, Karydaki's procedures are for chronic pilonidal disease.

Other options :

Options A - Hidradenitis suppurativa refers to follicular occlusion, folliculitis and secondary infection with skin flora. This leads to chronic suppurative, painful, skin abscesses, sinus tracts, and scarring. It usually occurs in skin containing apocrine glands, like the axillae and groins. It runs in the caudad direction while pilonidal sinus runs in a cephalad direction. They are usually found in the perineum while pilonidal sinus is found in the natal cleft. 

The following image shows a hidradenitis suppurativa lesion with multiple boils and points of discharge.

Option C - Anal fistula is an abnormal communication, that runs outwards from the anorectal lumen to an external opening on the skin of the perineum or buttocks. It presents with bloody discharge and in some cases feces in the sinus tract while a pilonidal abscess/sinus does not. The internal opening is usually palpated as a point of induration in rectal examination.

Options D - Postanal dermoid is a cystic condition that usually remains asymptomatic until adult life. Hair is not found in the sinus tract. The cyst is easily palpable on rectal examination. Pressure over the sacrococcygeal region with a finger in the rectum may cause a flow of sebaceous material. A bottle-necked cyst is visualized in the front of the coccyx upon injection of contrast media followed by radiography. Given the background of serving in the military, postanal dermoid is less likely to be the answer to this question.

questions.text: Calculate the tidal volume if the respiratory rate is 15/min and the alveolar ventilation is 6 L/min. (Consider dead space volume to be 150 mL)
questions.solution:
Alveolar ventilation = RR X (VT –VD)

In the given case,

  • Respiratory rate (RR)= 15/min
  • Alveolar ventilation = 6 L/min
  • Dead space volume (VD) = 150 mL
  • Tidal volume (VT) =?

Thus,

6000 (in mL/min) = 15 X (VT -150)

6000/15 = VT -150

400 + 150 = VT

550 mL = VT

questions.text: A 44-year-old female patient with breast cancer comes for her second round of chemotherapy. She reveals that she had severe vomiting during and after her first round of chemotherapy. A drug with which of the following mechanisms of action is not effective in controlling this patient's emesis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette shows a patient undergoing chemotherapy. A drug not effective in controlling this patient's emesis is a histamine H1 antagonist.

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy presents with a history of injury to the eye caused while climbing a tree 5 days ago; the injury has caused pain, photophobia, and redness of the eye for 2 days. Slit-lamp examination reveals a lesion as shown below. Which of the following is a feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the image of an ulcer with irregular feathery margins are suggestive of a fungal corneal ulcer. Satellite lesions are a feature of fungal ulcers.

A fungal corneal ulcer is usually caused by trauma with vegetative or organic matter. Signs are more pronounced than symptoms. The corneal ulcer appears dry.

Causative organisms:

  • Aspergillus
  • Fusarium
  • Candida albicans

Signs of a fungal ulcer:

  • Irregular margins of the ulcer
  • Presence of satellite lesions surrounding the ulcer.
  • An immune ring (Wesseley ring) may be seen around the ulcer due to the deposition of the immune complexes.
  • Slough is usually dry, with feathery borders surrounded by a yellow line of demarcation.
  • Hypopyon may be present or absent. If present, it is thick, and immobile due to the direct invasion of the fungal hyphae into the anterior chamber.

Treatment:

  • Topical drugs: These include topical natamycin, voriconazole, or amphotericin B drops, which are effective against Aspergillus and Fusarium. Nystatin is effective against Candida.
  • Systemic drugs: Severe ulcers with hypopyon, perforation, or suspected endophthalmitis might warrant the use of oral antifungal agents such as ketoconazole or voriconazole.

Other options :

Option A: Reverse hypopyon is the collection of emulsified silicone oil in the anterior chamber. Here, emulsified silicone bubbles are coalesced and seen in the upper part of the anterior chamber (AC). 

Option B: Dendritic ulcer is seen in epithelial keratitis caused by the herpes simplex virus. An image of a dendritic ulcer with fluorescein dye is shown below.

Option C: Ring abscess is seen in helminthic keratitis, especially that caused by Acanthamoeba. Gradual enlargement and coalescence of infiltrates occur, leading to the formation of an abscess.

questions.text: A woman presents with progressive swelling of the lower limb, as shown below. On examination, there is non-pitting edema associated with the thickening of the skin. Which type of biological transmission is seen in this disease?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of progressive unilateral lower limb edema, which is non-pitting and associated with thickening of the skin, is suggestive of lymphatic filariasis. The microfilaria of the causative agent W. bancrofti undergoes cyclo-developmental biological transmission. 

Lymphatic filariasis occurs due to the transmission of Wuchereria bancrofti by the bite of Culex mosquitoes. It undergoes only developmental changes and no multiplication in the vector, known as cyclo-developmental transmission.

Epidemiological classification of vector-borne diseases by methods in which vectors are involved in the transmission and propagation of parasites : 

Mechanical transmission: Here, an arthropod carries the infectious agent by either crawling or flying or is excreted by the vector at the site of infection. The infectious organism does not undergo multiplication or development during its transmission by the vector.

Biological transmission: The vector serves as a site for development, multiplication, or both for the infectious agent. It is of three types :

  • Propagative
  • Cyclo-propagative
  • Cyclo-developmental

The image below demonstrates the life-cyle of Wuchereria bancrofti:

Related Pearl: Biological Transmission in Vector-Borne Diseases

1. Propagative

  • The disease agent only multiplies in the vector and there is no change in form.
  • E.g., Plague bacilli in rat fleas.

2. Cyclo-propagative

  • The agent changes in form and in number.
  • E.g., Malarial parasites in mosquitoes.

3. Cyclo-developmental

  • The agent undergoes only developmental changes and not multiplication.
  • E.g., Microfilaria in mosquitoes.

4. Transovarial

  • Infectious agent is transmitted vertically in the vector, from parent to progeny.
  • E.g., Rickettsia rickettsii in ticks.

5. Transstadial

  • The infectious agent stays with the vector from one stage of its life cycle to the next.
  • E.g., Borrelia burgdorferi in ticks.

questions.text: A patient is planned to undergo tympanoplasty. In which type of tympanoplasty is the graft placed in contact with the structure marked in the given image, according to Wullstein's classification?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the given image is the incus. Type II tympanoplasty is performed when the malleus is eroded due to middle ear disease and the graft is placed on the incus.

The incus is one of the three ossicles of the middle ear. It has a body and a short process, both of which lie in the attic and can be identified by the long process that hangs vertically and attaches to the head of the stapes.

Tympanoplasty is the surgical reconstruction to correct damage in the middle ear and restore the integrity of the tympanic membrane. It involves ossiculoplasty (reconstruction of the ossicular chain) with or without myringoplasty.

The main objective of the procedure is the eradication of middle ear disease with the reconstruction of the tympanic membrane and ossicles.

Myringoplasty is the term given for the closure of perforation of pars tensa of tympanic membrane done to check repeated infections from the external ear.

Type Defect and repair
Type I Perforation of tympanic membrane which is repaired with a graft (myringoplasty)
Type II Perforation of tympanic membrane with erosion of malleus. The graft is placed on the incus or remnant of the malleus.
Type III Malleus and incus are absent. The graft is placed directly on the stapes head (myringostapediopexy)
Type IV Only the footplate of stapes is present. The graft is placed between the oval and round windows on the stapes footplate
Type V The stapes footplate is fixed but the round window is functioning. The graft is placed in contact with a new window created on the fenestra in the horizontal semicircular canal

 

Related Pearl: Zollner and Wullstein’s classification/ Types of tympanoplasty

Type Findings Procedure
Graft placed over
Type I (or) Myringoplasty All ossicles are intact Over/ under remnant TM over the handle of malleus
Type II Malleus eroded Over the remnant malleus/ incus
Type III (or) Columella (or) Myringostapediopexy Malleus & incus absent Over stapes superstructure
Type IV (or) Cavum minor All ossicles eroded Over ET and the round window, leaving mobile footplate exposed
Type V (or) Fenestration surgery Fixed footplate An opening made in the lateral semicircular canal (an alternative pathway)
Type VI (or) Sono-Inversion --- The round window is left exposed and receives sound and the oval window is covered (reversed pathway)

Type III is called columella because it resembles the middle ear of birds. They have a single ossicle. Type VI is not part of the original Zollner-Wullstein classification. It is a recent addition.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented to the OPD with a painful genital ulcer on the glans penis. Examination reveals regional lymph nodes which are enlarged and painful. Which of the following is the most probable causative organism?
questions.solution:
A painful genital ulcer with enlarged and painful regional lymph nodes is suggestive of chancroid caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

Chancroid (soft sore) is an acute STD caused by anaerobic gram-negative coccobacilli Haemophilus ducreyi. Chancroid ulcers are characterized by tender non-indurated irregular ulcers on the genitalia and are associated with painful inguinal lymphadenopathy.

It is Gram-negative but may often appear Gram-positive and frequently shows bipolar staining. The bacilli may be arranged in small groups or whorls or in parallel chains, giving a 'school of fish' or 'rail road track' appearance. Chocolate agar with isovitaleX is the suitable culture medium for Haemophilus ducreyi. H.ducreyi requires the presence of factor X but not factor V.

Management includes various antibiotics like erythromycin, cotrimoxazole, ciprofloxacin, and ceftriaxone.

questions.text: A young man presents with vomiting, nausea, and epigastric pain. He has been on proton-pump inhibitors for the past year. An endoscopy revealed multiple well-circumscribed polyps with a smooth surface, located on the gastric body and fundus. Shown below is a histopathological image of the polyp. Which of the following is this condition most likely associated with?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and site of the polyps are highly suggestive of fundic gland polyps. This condition is most likely associated with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP).

Fundic gland polyps usually occur at a mean age of 50 years. They are commonly found in the gastric body and fundus. These polyps may occur sporadically with proton-pump inhibitor use or due to mutation of the APC gene. APC gene mutation is also associated with familial adenomatous polyposis and hence is a possible risk factor for the development of fundic gland polyps.

They may be asymptomatic or associated with nausea, vomiting, or epigastric pain. Dysplasia, and even cancer, may occur in FAP-associated fundic gland polyps. But sporadic polyps due to proton pump inhibitors use do not progress to neoplastic conditions. Another gastric polyp associated with FAP is gastric adenoma.

Histological image of fundic gland polyp showing cystically dilated, irregular glands lined by flattened parietal and chief cells. Inflammation is typically absent or minimal.

Other options: 

Option A: Chronic gastritis - Multiple, smooth, hyperplastic, or inflammatory polyps that are <1 cm in size occur in chronic gastritis. On histology, they show irregular, cystically dilated, and elongated foveolar glands with edematous lamina propria. Variable degrees of inflammation are present.

Option B: Zollinger-Ellison syndrome - It is due to the presence of gastrin-secreting neuroendocrine tumors in the small intestine or pancreas. The oxyntic mucosa of the stomach is thickened due to massive parietal cell hyperplasia.

Option C: Peutz-Jeghers syndrome - This is a rare autosomal dominant syndrome characterized by multiple GI hamartomatous polyps and mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation. Histology shows a characteristic branching or arborizing network of connective tissue, smooth muscle, lamina propria, and glands lined by a normal-appearing intestinal epithelium. The following image shows the histology of a polyp in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

Related Pearl: Features of Familial Adenomatous Polyposis

Gastrointestinal manifestations:

  • Colon and rectum: Multiple adenomatous polyps usually >100
  • Gastric and duodenal polyps are present
  • Gastric polyp: fundal gland polyp, gastric adenoma
  • Duodenal polyp usually in the ampullary region: Adenomatous and premalignant

Extraintestinal manifestations

  • Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE) is seen. It is detected by indirect ophthalmoscopy.
  • Epidermoid cysts
  • Desmoid tumors in the abdomen
  • Osteoma in the skull, mandible, and tibia
  • Brain tumors
  • Tumors of the thyroid, adrenal, liver, pancreas, gallbladder, and bile duct

questions.text: The electrocardiograph of a neonate, presenting with the following facial rash, is suggestive of a complete heart block. Which of the following antibodies are most likely to be associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given findings of a periorbital rash with ECG findings of a complete heart block are suggestive of neonatal lupus erythematosus. It is most likely to be associated with anti-Ro antibodies.

Neonatal lupus results from the passive transfer of maternal IgG autoantibodies (anti-Ro and anti-La) to the fetus. Hence, mothers with a known history of SLE or those who are positive for autoantibodies should undergo screening with fetal echocardiography. Detection of anti-Ro antibodies in a newborn is specific for neonatal lupus syndrome.

Clinical manifestations of neonatal lupus include a characteristic annular or macular rash typically affecting the face (especially the periorbital area), trunk, and scalp. The rash typically appears within the first 6 weeks of life after exposure to ultraviolet light and may last for 3-4 months.

The most feared complication is congenital heart block. Conduction system abnormalities range from prolongation of the PR interval to complete heart block. In severe cases, they can develop progressive cardiomyopathy. Conduction system abnormalities can be detected in utero by fetal echocardiogram beginning at 16 weeks of gestational age. Other noncardiac features include hepatitis, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia.

Treatment options include corticosteroids (dexamethasone or betamethasone), intravenous immunoglobulins, plasmapheresis, hydroxychloroquine, and terbutaline, which are given to pregnant women with anti-Ro or anti-La antibodies to prevent occurrence or progression of fetal cardiac abnormalities. Treatment for neonates is directed at specific organ involvement. With cardiac pacing, children with conduction system disease in the absence of cardiomyopathy have an excellent prognosis. 

Other Options:

Option A: Serology for rubella antibodies is done to confirm congenital rubella syndrome, which can have heart defects (most commonly patent ductus arteriosus). However, other features of the syndrome, like sensorineural hearing loss, blueberry muffin rash, and cataracts, are not present in this patient.

The given image shows a blueberry muffin rash seen in congenital rubella syndrome:

 

Option B: Serology for anti-treponemal antibodies is done to confirm congenital syphilis. Heart block and periorbital rash are not the features of congenital syphilis. In congenital syphilis, the maculopapular rash is characteristically present on the palms and soles. There will be hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, and elevated liver enzymes.

The given image shows maculopapular rash in congenital syphilis involving the soles:

 

Option C: Serology for anti-dsDNA antibodies is a highly specific test to diagnose systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Features of SLE include malar rash, arthralgia, serositis, etc. These antibodies will be present in the mother but not in the baby.

The given image shows malar rash in SLE:

Related Pearl: Antibodies in Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)

More common in black & asians than white

More common in blacks and whites

questions.text:
A 25-year-old patient was scheduled for a tonsillectomy. Endotracheal intubation was performed after placing the patient under general anesthesia. Sequentially arrange the following steps of intubation from first to last:
  1. Introduction of laryngoscope
  2. Check breath sounds with a stethoscope
  3. Neck extension and flexion
  4. Inflation of tube cuff
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of steps is 3-1-4-2.

Correct positioning of the patient is essential for adequate glottis exposure during laryngoscopy. The patient is typically placed in the sniffing position with:

  • Moderate head elevation (7-9 cm above the surgical table)
  • Atlantooccipital joint extension
  • Flexion of the lower portion of the cervical spine by resting the head on a pillow

 The image below shows the following steps of endotracheal intubation:

Related Pearl: Signs of correct endotracheal intubation

  • Detection of end-tidal CO2 by capnography (Surest confirmation)
  • Symmetric chest rise
  • Bilateral breath sounds
  • Absence of breath sounds in the epigastrium
  • Visible condensation in the endotracheal tube
  • Large exhaled tidal volumes
  • Appropriate compliance of the reservoir bag during manual ventilation

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.
